ai-ud5.4:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-ud5.4:1.3_0: Now at that time, between Sāvatthī and the Jeta Grove, several boys were catching little fish.
ai-ud5.4:2.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-ud5.4:2.2_0: He saw the boys tormenting the fish.
ai-ud5.4:2.3_0: He went to them and said,
ai-ud5.4:2.4_0: “Are you afraid, boys, of suffering? Is suffering unpleasant to you?”
ai-ud5.4:2.5_0: “Yes, reverend Sir, we are afraid of suffering, suffering is unpleasant to us.”
ai-ud5.4:3.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud5.4:5.1_0: If you should do a bad deed,
ai-ud5.4:5.3_0: you won’t be freed from suffering,
ai-ud5.4:5.4_0: though you fly away and flee.”
